bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Joseph H. White, November 11, 1922

div1.p: Rose reports on a yellow fever outbreak in Ceara, Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Joseph H. White, November 11, 1922
div1.opener:
Copy for Dr. Carter
November 11, 1922
Dear Doctor White:
div1.p:
In an interview with me yesterday Mr. C. A. Neff, civil
engineer on the staff of Dwight P. Robinson & Company, reported that
the prevalence of yellow fever in Ceara had neccesitated the quaran-
tine of a hotel in Fortaleza called “La France ” against foreigners.
Natives are permitted to go there. The quarantine was ordered by
the local doctors but they refuse to admit the existence of yellow
fever. It is generally understood, however, that there have been many
cases. Mr. Neff personally knows of seven cases with five deaths
since February.

As you know, an epidemic was reported in Ceara during Aug-
ust, though its diagnosis as yellow fever was disputed. An American
citizen died of yellow fever in Ceara on October 18, and a supply of
vaccine was immediately shipped to Doctor Hackett.

Mr. Neff believes that there is no evidence of the existence
of yellow fever in Para (Bolem).

We shall keep you advised of any further reports from this
region.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, WICKLIFFE ROSE Doctor J. H. White
Paseo de la Reforma 93
Mexico City, Mexico
